query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
1 Come l’augello, intra l’amate fronde, 2 posato al nido de’ suoi dolci nati 3 la notte che le cose ci nasconde,
4 che, per veder li aspetti disïati 5 e per trovar lo cibo onde li pasca, 6 in che gravi labor li sono aggrati,
7 previene il tempo in su aperta frasca, 8 e con ardente affetto il sole aspetta, 9 fiso guardando pur che l’alba nasca;
10 così la donna mïa stava eretta 11 e attenta, rivolta inver’ la plaga 12 sotto la quale il sol mostra men fretta:
13 sì che, veggendola io sospesa e vaga, 14 fecimi qual è quei che disïando 15 altro vorria, e sperando s’appaga.
query.result:
1 As the bird, within the beloved branches, 2 settled at the nest of its sweet young, 3 the night that hides things from us,
4 that, to see the desired aspects 5 and to find the food with which it feeds them, 6 in which heavy labors are burdened upon it,
7 anticipates the time on an open branch, 8 and with ardent affection awaits the sun, 9 fixedly watching until the dawn is born;
10 thus my lady was standing 11 and attentive, turned towards the region 12 under which the sun shows less haste:
13 so that, seeing her suspended and wandering, 14 she made me as is he who desiring 15 another would want, and hoping is satisfied.

16 But little was there between one and the other when, 17 of my waiting, I say, and of seeing 18 the sky coming more and more illuminated;
19 and Beatrice said: “Behold the hosts 20 of the triumph of Christ and all the fruit 21 reaped from the turning of these spheres!”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
22 Pariemi che ’l suo viso ardesse tutto, 23 e li occhi avea di letizia sì pieni, 24 che passarmen convien sanza costrutto.
query.result: 22 It seemed to me that her face was burning all over, 23 and her eyes had so much joy, 24 that I must pass beyond without construction.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
25 Quale ne’ plenilunïi sereni 26 Trivïa ride tra le ninfe etterne 27 che dipingon lo ciel per tutti i seni,
28 vid’ i’ sopra migliaia di lucerne 29 un sol che tutte quante l’accendea, 30 come fa ’l nostro le viste superne;
31 e per la viva luce trasparea 32 la lucente sustanza tanto chiara 33 nel viso mio, che non la sostenea.

Please translate each line literally into English.
34 Oh Bëatrice, dolce guida e cara! 35 Ella mi disse: «Quel che ti sobranza 36 è virtù da cui nulla si ripara.
query.result: 34 Oh Beatrice, sweet guide and dear! 35 She said to me: “That which overwhelms you 36 is virtue from which nothing is defended.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
37 Quivi è la sapïenza e la possanza 38 ch’aprì le strade tra ’l cielo e la terra, 39 onde fu già sì lunga disïanza».
query.result: 37 Here is the wisdom and the power 38 that opened the roads between heaven and earth, 39 whence was already such long distance.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
40 Come foco di nube si diserra 41 per dilatarsi sì che non vi cape, 42 e fuor di sua natura in giù s’atterra,
43 la mente mia così, tra quelle dape 44 fatta più grande, di sé stessa uscìo, 45 e che si fesse rimembrar non sape.
query.result:
40 As fire from a cloud unravels 41 to expand so that it does not fit, 42 and outside of its nature downwards it lands,
43 my mind thus, among those things, 44 became larger, from itself it went out, 45 and did not know how to be remembered.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
46 «Apri li occhi e riguarda qual son io; 47 tu hai vedute cose, che possente 48 se’ fatto a sostener lo riso mio».

Please translate each line literally into English.
49 Io era come quei che si risente 50 di visïone oblita e che s’ingegna 51 indarno di ridurlasi a la mente,
52 quand’ io udi’ questa proferta, degna 53 di tanto grato, che mai non si stingue 54 del libro che ’l preterito rassegna.
query.result:
49 I was like one who remembers 50 of a forgotten vision and who strives 51 in vain to reduce it to the mind,
52 when I heard this utterance, worthy 53 of such gratitude, that never extinguishes 54 the book that reviews the past.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
55 Se mo sonasser tutte quelle lingue 56 che Polimnïa con le suore fero 57 del latte lor dolcissimo più pingue,
58 per aiutarmi, al millesmo del vero 59 non si verria, cantando il santo riso 60 e quanto il santo aspetto facea mero;
61 e così, figurando il paradiso, 62 convien saltar lo sacrato poema, 63 come chi trova suo cammin riciso.

Please translate each line literally into English.
64 Ma chi pensasse il ponderoso tema 65 e l’omero mortal che se ne carca, 66 nol biasmerebbe se sott’ esso trema:
67 non è pareggio da picciola barca 68 quel che fendendo va l’ardita prora, 69 né da nocchier ch’a sé medesmo parca.
query.result:
64 But whoever thought the weighty theme 65 and the mortal shoulder that carries it, 66 would not blame it if beneath it trembles:
67 it is not equal to a small boat 68 that which cleaving goes the daring prow, 69 nor from a steersman who to himself is sparing.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
70 «Perché la faccia mia sì t’innamora, 71 che tu non ti rivolgi al bel giardino 72 che sotto i raggi di Cristo s’infiora?
73 Quivi è la rosa in che ’l verbo divino 74 carne si fece; quivi son li gigli 75 al cui odor si prese il buon cammino».
query.result:
70 “Because my face so enchants you, 71 that you do not turn to the beautiful garden 72 that under the rays of Christ flowers?
73 There is the rose in which the divine word 74 became flesh; there are the lilies 75 to whose scent the good path was taken.”

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
76 Così Beatrice; e io, che a’ suoi consigli 77 tutto era pronto, ancora mi rendei 78 a la battaglia de’ debili cigli.
query.result: 76 Thus Beatrice; and I, who to her counsels 77 was all ready, still I gave myself 78 to the battle of weak eyelids.

79 As to a ray of sun, that purely strikes 80 through dense cloud, already a meadow of flowers 81 I saw, covered with shadow, my eyes;
82 I saw thus more crowds of splendors, 83 flashed down from above by burning rays, 84 without seeing the beginning of flashes.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
85 O benigna vertù che sì li ’mprenti, 86 sù t’essaltasti, per largirmi loco 87 a li occhi lì che non t’eran possenti.
query.result: 85 O benevolent virtue that so imprints them, 86 up you exalted yourself, to widen space for me 87 to the eyes there who were not powerful to you.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
88 Il nome del bel fior ch’io sempre invoco 89 e mane e sera, tutto mi ristrinse 90 l’animo ad avvisar lo maggior foco;
91 e come ambo le luci mi dipinse 92 il quale e il quanto de la viva stella 93 che là sù vince come qua giù vinse,
94 per entro il cielo scese una facella, 95 formata in cerchio a guisa di corona, 96 e cinsela e girossi intorno ad ella.

Please translate each line literally into English.
97 Qualunque melodia più dolce suona 98 qua giù e più a sé l’anima tira, 99 parrebbe nube che squarciata tona,
100 comparata al sonar di quella lira 101 onde si coronava il bel zaffiro 102 del quale il ciel più chiaro s’inzaffira.
query.result:
97 Whatever melody sounds sweeter down here 98 and more draws the soul to itself, 99 would seem a cloud that, split, thunders,
100 compared to the sound of that lyre 101 with which was crowned the beautiful sapphire 102 with which the sky becomes more sapphire-like.

103 «I am angelic love, that circles 104 the high joy that breathes from the womb 105 that was lodging of our desire;
106 and I will circle, lady of heaven, while 107 you follow your son, and will make day 108 more the highest hope so that he enters there».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
109 Così la circulata melodia 110 si sigillava, e tutti li altri lumi 111 facean sonare il nome di Maria.
query.result: 109 Thus the circling melody 110 sealed itself, and all the other lights 111 made sound the name of Mary.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
112 Lo real manto di tutti i volumi 113 del mondo, che più ferve e più s’avviva 114 ne l’alito di Dio e nei costumi,
115 avea sopra di noi l’interna riva 116 tanto distante, che la sua parvenza, 117 là dov’ io era, ancor non appariva:
118 però non ebber li occhi miei potenza 119 di seguitar la coronata fiamma 120 che si levò appresso sua semenza.
query.result:
112 The royal mantle of all the volumes 113 of the world, that more boils and more is enlivened 114 in the breath of God and in the habits,
115 had above us the inner shore 116 so distant, that its appearance, 117 there where I was, still did not appear:
118 therefore my eyes did not have the power 119 to follow the crowned flame 120 that rose near its seed.

121 And as a little child who towards the mother 122 extends the arms, after that he took the milk, 123 for the spirit that even from outside inflames;
124 each one of those whitenesses upwards stretched 125 with its peak, so that the high affection 126 that they had for Mary was made clear to me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
127 Indi rimaser lì nel mio cospetto, 128 ‘Regina celi’ cantando sì dolce, 129 che mai da me non si partì ’l diletto.
query.result: 127 Then remained there in my sight, 128 ‘Queen of Heaven’ singing so sweetly, 129 that never from me departed the delight.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
130 Oh quanta è l’ubertà che si soffolce 131 in quelle arche ricchissime che fuoro 132 a seminar qua giù buone bobolce!
133 Quivi si vive e gode del tesoro 134 che s’acquistò piangendo ne lo essilio 135 di Babillòn, ove si lasciò l’oro.
query.result:
130 Oh how great is the abundance that is sheltered 131 in those very rich arches that were 132 to sow down here good little shoots!
133 There one lives and enjoys the treasure 134 that was acquired weeping in the exile 135 of Babylon, where he left the gold.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English.
136 Quivi trïunfa, sotto l’alto Filio 137 di Dio e di Maria, di sua vittoria, 138 e con l’antico e col novo concilio,
139 colui che tien le chiavi di tal gloria.
query.result:
136 There triumphs, under the high Son 137 of God and of Mary, of his victory, 138 and with the ancient and with the new council,
139 he who holds the keys of such glory.
